properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy continuing this afternoon. What: Heavy snow. Total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are expected with periods of very poor visibility. Where: Fraserdale - Pledger Lake. When: Heavy snow will continue to taper off before ending early this evening. Discussion: Bands of heavy snow are occurring in the area. Under these bands, snowfall rates of 2 to 5 cm per hour may be realized, resulting in rapid accumulation and poor visibility. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-12T01:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T16:16:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3990766282.2021
Area: Fraserdale - Pledger Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts today. What: Wind gusts of 70-80 km/h. Where: Bruce and Grey Counties. When: This afternoon into the early evening. Impacts: Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Discussion: Strong wind gusts are expected this afternoon in the wake of a strong cold front. Winds will gradually weaken this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-12T01:59:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T16:35:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3358083402.2021
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A complex storm is set to arrive today. An approaching Pacific front will become nearly stationary on a line from the North Coast to Haida Gwaii tonight through Friday. Heavy precipitation and strong winds will accompany this storm. Current model guidance suggests that Haida Gwaii and the North Coast could receive significant snowfall on Friday, whereas to the south of the front, Terrace and Kitimat area are expected to see heavy rainfall. Stewart will also see a prolonged period of snowfall tonight through Saturday. Snowfall and rainfall amounts for this event are still to be determined at the moment due to the uncertainty of the position of the front. Weather alerts may be issued at a later time as forecast confidence increases. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-12T10:26:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T18:27:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4207879218.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 4:14 p.m. EST, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts. This line of severe thunderstorms is located from Marion Lake to Wood Bay, moving east at 40 km/h. Locations impacted include: Gravenhurst, Bracebridge, Hardy Lake Provincial Park, Baysville, J. Albert Bauer Provincial Park and Oxtongue River-Ragged Falls Provincial . ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2021-03-11T23:22:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T21:15:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4098466008.2021
Area: Western Algonquin Park - Lake of Two Rivers, Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst, Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with visibilities less than 400 metres are expected to develop this morning. An approaching low pressure system will impact the Mackenzie Delta today and into Friday. Falling snow and strong northwesterly winds will combine to drop visibilities to below 400 metres for much of the day today. Conditions will improve late this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-12T09:30:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-11T17:31:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2303081350.2021
Area: Aklavik Region

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL (March 10, 2021 10:00 - Kamloops) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-12T07:39:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-11T15:40:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0566776919.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. What: Heavy rain. Total accumulations of 20 to 40 mm are expected. Where: From Elliot Lake to Gogama When: Continuing this morning. Discussion: Rain will continue this morning. Rainfall accumulations of 20 to 40 mm are anticipated. The ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall due to it being frozen and snow covered. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm by Saturday morning. Maximum wind gusts Friday: easterly up to 60 km/h . Maximum wind gusts Friday night: northerly up to 80 km/h Locations: Nain to Makkovik Time span: Beginning Friday morning and persisting into Saturday. Remarks: Snow and blowing snow will develop Friday morning and then persist through Friday night and into Saturday. Near-zero visibilities in white-out conditions are expected at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are expected by Friday evening. The snow combined with moderate winds will cause blowing snow which will significantly reduce visibilities. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow today. What: Heavy snow. Total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are expected. Where: Fort Albany and Moosonee. When: This morning through midnight. Discussion: Periods of heavy snow are expected today, with rapid snowfall accumulation and associated poor visibility. Ice pellets and some freezing rain are also possible this afternoon near or southeast of Moosonee. Snow will weaken this evening but continue until near midnight with a couple of additional centimetres possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
